Sub: Addressing issues faced by Sikh passengers regarding Kirpan at Indian
Airports: Rea.

Reference is invited to the representation received from Amritsar Vikas Manch regarding
the difficulties faced by Sikh passengers at Indian airports while wearing Sikh religious articles
of faith,

2 Vide" letter, it has been informed that Amritsar Vikas Manch has received numerous
reports from Sikh passengers traveling on international flights from India. These passengers
have reported that CISF personnel at Indian airports are compelling them to remove even small
(1-inch or smaller) Kirpans worn as necklaces or souvenirs. Some Sikh passengers have raised
concems that this treatment amounts to racial profiling, as passengers of other faiths wearing
small Trishuls or Crosses do not face similar restrictions. This directive appears to stem from a
misunderstanding regarding the distinction between small articles of faith and the larger
Kirpans, which are permitted on domestic flights but restricted on international flights.

3. In this regard, | have been directed to request you to sensitize ASG personnel to
exercise better application of reason while allowing/disallowing certain items during security
check process if the same has not been specifically mentioned in the list of prohibited items by
BCAS, considering factors such as edge (sharp/blunt), souvenir or replica etc. and its potential
to jeopardize the safety and security of civil aviation operations. Meanwhile, it is of utmost
importance that no security norms are compromised. It is also requested to sensitize personnel
to be polite, courteous, careful and tactful while handling such sensitive sentimental issues.

4 This has been issued with the approval of the Competent Authority.
